answers.answer: Hi.  I'm not a medical professional, just the parent of a kid with diabetes.  My daughter was 7 when she was diagnosed with diabetes, so I haven't dealt specifically with toddler issues, although I know many people who are.  It's definitely not an easy thing to deal with.  Hypoglycemia is a little different from diabetes in how it's treated, so I apologize in advance if I confuse the two.I think you're asking two separate questions here, at least that's how I'll address them.  The first is about how to handle managing the hypoglycemia of a toddler that isn't able to communicate or recognize lows.  The second is to be able to explain what happened in that particular incident.How often do you test blood sugars?  I presume you test prior to going to bed.  Do you test in the middle of the night?  Overnights are the most concerning times because there isn't eye-on the child all time.  A couple extra tests a night until you are sure she isn't going to go low and would be an excellent way to prevent problems.  It really sucks as a parent to not have interrupted sleep, but it's much better than the alternative of spending the day in the ER, or worse.  Another alternative that is becoming more available is a Continuous Glucose Monitor (CGM).  It is a monitor that has sensors which go under the skin and test blood sugars every 5 minutes.  It gives alarm warmings when the person goes high and especially when the person is going low.  It's not inexpensive, startup costs are about a thousand dollars, and it's a couple hundred for supplies every month, but many insurance companies are covering CGM and supplies.  It can give great information about trends and whether or not what you are using for ratios and correction factors are correct.  Most importantly, it warns of lows long before they cause seizures.  I think that a hypoglycemic can be approved for a CGM, but I don't know for sure.  It's definitely worth checking into, if you're interested.As for the second question about what happened in that particular incident, it's important to know that when a hypoglycemic (or a diabetic) has a seizure, it often takes many hours, and even a day or two, for the person to fully recover.  They will show symptoms like they aren't quite right for a while, because it takes a bit for the glucose to get back into the system and get things "woken back up", so to speak.  So for her to not be herself is completely expected.Then there are the two lows, one in the middle of the night and one the next day.  Lots of things can cause blood sugars to go low.  Exercise causes the body to use glucose without needing insulin, and lots of exercise can cause the body to use extra glucose for hours after the exercise is done.  Swimming, for example, causes my daughter's blood sugar to srop like a rock.  Stress can cause blood sugars to go high as well, and conversely, excitement or anxiety can cause them to go low.  I'm not sure how much anxiety a toddler can have, but exercise and excitement are regular occurances, I'm sure.  On days that are more active than usual, it would be a good thing to check more often, such as 2 hours and 5 hours after the exercise is over, even if it's during the day, and particularly prior to the next meal.Does this help?
